div.p: Languages exhibit a tremendous amount of variation in how they organise and order morphemes within words; however, regularities are also found. For example, gender and number inflectional morphology tend to appear together within a single affix. In the relatively rare cases in which they appear as two separate affixes, morphology encoding gender information tends to be placed closer to the stem than number morphology is. Alternative theories of gender and number have been designed (in part) to explain these tendencies. However, the typological data are very sparse, making it difficult to find clear evidence for the representations and mechanisms shaping the organisation of gender and number. Across a series of experiments, we use an artificial language learning paradigm to explore the inferences learners make about the order of gender and number affixes in the absence of any explicit information in the input. We show that language learners have a clear preference for placing nominal morphology containing gender information closest to the stem. This holds both for prefixing and suffixing morphology, and across different types of gender and number systems. Importantly, these biases are consistent across populations of participants with different L1 experience with gender morphology: English, Italian and Kîîtharaka speakers. These results provide a new source of empirical support for particular theories of gender, and in line with previous work, suggest that cognitive biases play a role in determining morpheme order in the world's languages.

div.head: Introduction
div.p: Languages differ what kinds of information encode in their morphology, how they encoded it in individual morphemes, and how those morphemes are organised into complex words. Despite this variation, one prominent class of regularities relates to how morphemes are ordered (Bybee, 1985;Greenberg, 1963). For example, derivational affixes (which change a stem's category or meaning) tend to appear closer to the stem than inflectional affixes (which do not). Similar trends are found for inflectional morphology. For example, when distinct affixes exist for number (e.g., plural) and case (e.g., accusative) and they appear together, number is ordered closer to the stem than case (Greenberg, 1963). While these observations have typically been made in the context of typological description or theoretical linguistics, there is a growing body of research which attempts to provide behavioural evidence to explain these kinds of ordering generalisations as the output of cognitive biases active during language learning (e.g., Maldonado, Saldana, & Culbertson, 2020;Mansfield et al., 2022;Saldana, Oseki, & Culbertson, 2021) and processing (e.g., Gibson et al., 2013;Hahn, Degen, & Futrell, 2021;Hawkins & Cutler, 1988;Hay, 2001). For example, previous research has shown that when people are trained on a novel artificial language that has separative case and number morphology, but no information about their relative order, they infer that number should be closer to the stem than case (Saldana et al., 2021). Here we apply this approach with the aim of better understanding the mechanisms which drive the linearisation of gender and number morphology. The interaction of gender and number is substantially more complex than number and case, and the typological data about how they are linearised is much more sparse. Nevertheless formal theories of gender and number make clear predictions, often based on this sparse data, about how humans represent these morphological categories. Below, we highlight aspects and issues in gender typology, discuss evidence for how gender and number are realised together, and outline theories and predictions about how learners might preferentially order them. We then report the results of artificial language learning experiments testing these predictions. To preview, we find that language learners have a clear preference for placing nominal morphology containing gender information closer to the stem than number information, thus revealing asymmetries between gender and number dependencies with the noun stem and suggesting that they are not processed at the same level in their realisation.

div.head: The typology of gender systems
div.p: Gender (or noun class) 1 is an inflectional feature found in many languages, which categorises nouns into two or more classes. By definition, gender is reflected not only on the noun but also in agreement morphology on elements external to the noun (e.g., determiners, verbs, auxiliaries or adjectives; Corbett, 1991). In languages with gender, various properties of nouns (and sometimes pronouns) often play a role in determining which gender class a noun falls into. While nouns can be assigned to gender classes arbitrarily, assignment can also be based on phonological or morphological features (e.g., French nouns that end in on are typically masculine gender; Italian nouns with the derivational suffix -zione are always feminine gender). Notably however, there is almost always a semantic core to gender assignment (see fig. 1 below); nouns in a given gender class will tend to show some overlap in their semantic features, even if normally only for a subset of them. This 1 As is typical in mainstream typological literature, here we treat gender and noun classes as the same phenomenon. We use the term gender in this paper as a hyperonym for the two. We will thus use "gender class" instead of "noun class" to refer to a subset of nouns which inflect with the same gender morphology and thus the same agreement pattern. Distribution of different "semantic cores" in gender systems reported in Grambank (Skirgård et al., 2023). Of the 1,318 language in this dataset, 641 (48.6%) are (unequivocally) reported to have gender distinctions. A total of 93% of these gender systems have a documented semantic core; in 41.8% of the langauges (from 40 different language families) this core is animacy-based, in 26.7% (from 39 different language families) is sex-based, and in 19.7% (from 38 different language families) is both sex-and animacy-based; only 4.8% of the languages (from 20 different language families) have a semantic core based on some other property.foot_0 subset of nouns (unlike the rest within the same gender class) can thus be considered to have gender assignment based on their semantics, that is, semantic gender assignment.

Semantic gender assignment within gender systems with a semantic core generally involves nouns denoting entities which are animate, or sex-differentiable; for example, animate entities might be assigned to one gender class and inanimates to another, or female entities to one gender class and males to another. In this paper we refer to the gender systems where animacy is a factor for class assignment in a subset of nouns as animacy-based, and to the systems where perceived gender or biological sex is a factor for class assignment in a subset of nouns as sex-based (though note, that they can co-exist; Corbett, 1991;Kramer, 2015). Figure 1 illustrates the high frequency of these systems. Examples of systems with animacy-based gender assignment can be found in Bantu languages (Atlantic-Congo) such as Kîîtharaka (see 1; Kanampiu, Martin, & Culbertson, under review). In Kîîtharaka, gender and number are indicated cumulatively in a single prefix (on nouns and also on agreeing elements). The class 1 (1a) morpheme, for example, is used for human entities in the singular, the class 2 (1b) morpheme is used for those same entities in the plural. By contrast, classes 3 (1c) and 4 (1d) are used for the singular and plural of specific inanimate entities. 3Examples of systems with sex-based gender assignment can be found in Romance languages such as Italian (see 2-3). For example, in Italian, varying the gender of the noun stem indicating a particular type of animal denotes perceived biological gender: the same stem with -a or -o denotes the female or male entity respectively and will trigger the corresponding agreement (see 3). These nouns are often referred to as "common-gender" or "same root" nouns (Kramer, 2015). We will refer to this phenomenon as variable gender marking in opposition to fixed gender marking (e.g., 3). 5While fixed gender marking can be assigned according to semantic properties or not, variable gender is always assigned according to semantics. div.head: The interaction of gender with number and their realisation
div.p: Gender appears to interact in a special way with number morphology. While there are many languages that have number but not gender, languages with gender tend to also have number (Corbett, 1991(Corbett, , 2000)). Moreover, when both features are found in a language, gender and number are often marked via cumulative exponence (Corbett, 1991(Corbett, , 2000))-both features are marked with a single morpheme that is not further separable. For example, in Italian (see 2-3), noun suffixes all encode both gender and number (e.g., -a encodes FEM gender and SG number). Similarly, in Kîîtharaka (see 1), all prefixes encoding information about gender, also include number cumulatively. The cross-linguistic trend for gender and number morphology to be expressed cumulatively has been documented by Di Garbo (2014) in a sample of 100 languages (from 21 different families) spoken across Africa. She found that 81% percent of languages with gender have cumulative exponence of gender and number across all agreement targets, and 64% of languages that mark both gender and number on the noun also do it cumulatively.foot_5 This can also be seen in the AUTOTYP

When gender is marked via affixation, it tends to appear within the same affix as number cumulatively, both on nominals (100% in this sample) and on verbs (88%).

Separative or partially separative expressions of gender and number are rarer. A prototypical example of what can be described as separative gender and number morphology is found in Spanish (Indo-european). Spanish has a gender system similar to Italian (see 4-5), but number morphology can be described separately from gender on both nouns and agreement targets. Feminine nouns are typically indicated by a final vowel -a (e.g., 4a), and masculine with -o (e.g., 4c). Plural is then marked with the additional word-final affix -s (e.g., 4b and 4d). The same separative morphemes are found on agreement targets. Spanish and closely related Romance languages spoken in the Iberian peninsula like Catalan, Galician and Portuguese are often used as an example case (see, e.g., Fuchs, Polinsky, & Scontras, 2015) to illustrate what is thought to be the typical order of gender and number morphology when they can be descriptively separated: gender tends to appears closer to the stem than number. While there are no sufficiently large cross-linguistic surveys of separative gender-number exponence to assess this tendency robustly, the available evidence suggests that this likely is the case (e.g., Di Garbo, 2014).

Aside from these more straightforward examples, there are also cases in which gender information is encoded in some number morphemes but not others in a language. In these cases, there is further evidence of gender-closest orders. For example, in Wamey (Atlantic-Congo), the labial component common across most plural nouns classes vor wappears furthest away from the stem (see examples in 6; Jenkins & Jenkins, 2000;Santos, 1996). This labial segment has been analysed as a general plural marker which has been derived from what was originally the plural gender class 1 for human nouns (Santos, 1996). We find similar cases in other Atlantic-Congo families such as Bantu, where double plural marking can be used (allegedly with the same meaning as singleton plurals; Di Garbo, 2014). In these cases, a general plural marker (often a reanalysed human plural class marker) is placed furthest away from the stem, and the typical cumulative gender and number marker is placed closer. For example, in Kinshasa Lingala (Bokamba, 1977), the prefix ba-, typically used for plural human nouns (as in 7a) is argued to have been reanalysed as a general (redundant) plural marker. When used in this way, it precedes other gender-specific plural prefixes (as in 7b). In other words, the marker carrying gender information is closest to the noun stem. Similar examples of double plurals, where a class-independent general plural marker is placed further away from the stem than class-dependent plural marker can be found in Amharic (Kramer, 2016b).
The opposite order-a general plural appearing closer to stem-has not been described for double plurals in the literature.
That said, there are potential counterexamples to the general trend for gender-closest order.

For example, in Tachelhit Berber (Afro-Asiatic) MASC is unmarked, and FEM is marked with the prefix t-, which often appears as well as a -t suffix (as in 8a; Alderete, Jebbour, Kachoub, & Wilbee, 2015). For sex-differentiable referents, feminine nouns can be derived from masculine nouns by adding these t affixes (as in 8c). This can happen both in singular and plural forms. Plural MASC forms use a distinct initial vowel iacross both genders (as in 8d), as well as a plural suffix -in or -an for FEM and MASC genders respectively. In feminine plural nouns, we then observe the gender prefix t-(as in 8e) in the periphery, giving rise to a seemingly prefixal gender marker which is further away from the stem than the prefixal number marker (Alderete et al., 2015;Faust & Lahrouchi, 2022).

Interestingly, this is not the case for suffixes. When the number suffix -in (PL.FEM) appears together with the FEM suffix -t, the number affix appears farther from the stem (as in 8f Faust & Lahrouchi, 2022). While similar systems are found in other Berber languages (Di Garbo, 2014), no other clear such examples have been documented, and even these appear to have gender-closest orders as well. (8) Tachelhit Berber (Afro-Asiatic) a. tafukt FEM.sun.FEM b. afruX boy c. tafruXt FEM.girl d. ifrXan PL.boy.MASC.PL. e. tifrXin FEM.PL.girl.FEM.PL. f. tiKrdatin FEM.PL.mouse.FEM.PL.

To summarise, the typological evidence suggests that number and gender tend to be realised cumulatively. When they are expressed separately, it appears that gender is likely to appear closest to the stem; and in systems where the reverse order exists, gender-closest orders are also found.

However, the data on separative morphology here are notably sparse. Both trends nonetheless have factored into formal theories of gender and number, where several distinct proposals have been made for how these features are formalised and mentally represented.

div.head: Theories of gender and number representation, and their impact on morpheme ordering
div.p: Formal linguistic theories differ substantially in terms of how gender is argued to be represented, and in how it interacts with number. These theories have been designed (although not uniquely) to account for the kind of cross-linguistic data discussed above, and make different predictions about the kinds of inferences human learners might make when learning gender and number systems. In relation to our object of study, the main source of divergence across these different theories is whether gender is representationally distinct from number in nominal morphology.
In one well-known class of theories, gender is represented-i.e., projected in the syntaxseparately from number. Following Fuchs et al. (2015), we call these split models. Theories assum-

Indeed, there are proposals which argue that gender features are part of the lexical entry for a given noun. To account for these phenomena, lexicalist theories of gender often differentiate nouns that are specified for gender versus those which are unspecified (Alexiadou, 2004;Carstens et al., 2010;Harris, 1991;Roca, 1989). 9 Alternative theories which project the noun and gender features together use Distributed Morphology (Kihm, Cinque, & Kayne, 2005;Kramer, 2015;Lowenstamm, 2008). These accounts argue that nominal heads themselves have a more complex structure, with stems that are category neutral and a nominalising functional head, referred to as little n, where gender is located. Thus gender is within the nominal head and plays a role in turning a stem into a noun in a way that can be sensitive to semantics when necessary (see, e.g., Kihm et al., 2005;Kramer, 2015;Lowenstamm, 2008). There are also some split models which propose a distinction between variable and fixed gender nouns. For example, fixed gender might be projected within nP, and variable gender outside the nominal, within GenP (see Panagiotidis, 2018, for additional discussion of how this differs from a lexicalist model).

As with split models, within some bundling models fixed and variable gender is treated distinctly. For example, some bundling models argue that gender projects with number for variable (semantic) gender marking, but not for fixed gender, where it is considered to project with the nominal head (Carminati, 2005;De Vincenzi, 1999).

Split and bundling models capture different cross-linguistic tendencies regarding the interaction between gender and number morphology. If gender and number are bundled together and thus project together (as proposed by the bundling model), this predicts cumulative exponence, which is indeed extremely common. However, as discussed above, there are cases where the gender and number are expressed as separate morphemes. Moreover, there are many instances in which gender and number seem to act separately, even if they can be expressed cumulatively in other contexts.

For example, Romance languages such as Italian and Spanish-which have both number and gender morphology-have verbal agreement with the subject noun in number but not gender. These phenomena (amongst others) suggest that at the very least gender and number can project separately. This possibility is captured by split models. Even though these models may differ with regard to whether the representation of gender is an inherent part of the noun or a projecting head immediately dominating it, they all predict that gender should be placed closer to the stem than number in cases where the exponence of gender and number is non-cumulative, a tendency tentatively supported by the cross-linguistic data discussed above. By contrast, bundling models make no clear predictions about order (i.e., without further ad-hoc ordering mechanisms forcing number to linearise outside of gender Ritter, 1993).

div.head: Other explanations of gender and number morpheme ordering
div.p: The theories discussed above make predictions (or not) about order on the basis of structural morphosyntactic representations of gender and number. However, there are other explanations of morpheme order that are potentially relevant for gender. For example, Greenberg (1963) introduced the notion of proximity hierarchies for nominal morphology, essentially dictating which morphemes are closer to the stem than others. He speculated that this was "related to degrees of logical and psychological remoteness" from the stem (Greenberg, 1963, , p. 103). In his proposal, proximity hierarchies were also related to other implicational hierarchies relevant to inflectional categories, for example, regarding markedness or syncretism. For case and number morphology, Greenberg (1963) placed number higher on the proximity hierarchy (i.e., closer to the stem) than case based on a set of observations: (i) number almost always appears closer to the stem than case cross-linguistically (Universal 39; Greenberg, 1963), (ii) many languages with systematic number marking lack case but not vice versa, and (iii) case is more likely to be neutralised within a given number value than number is to be neutralised within a given case value (Baerman, Brown, & Corbett, 2005;Corbett, 1991Corbett, , 2000)). Building on these notions, Bybee (1985) developed the relevance hierarchy. Under her proposal, morphemes which are more relevant to the stem will be placed closer to it. For case and number morphology, she suggests that number appears closer to the stem because it directly modifies the entity referred to by the noun (i.e., it is very relevant to the noun). By contrast, the case morpheme signals an external relationship between the entity and some event (i.e., less relevant to the noun stem), thus it appears further away from the stem. Neither Greenberg (1963)'s notion of proximity hierarchies nor Bybee (1985)'s relevance hierarchy has been explicitly applied to other nominal inflectional features. However, for gender and number morphology, the general line of argumentation would likely be less straightforward. Number should be placed higher in the proximity hierarchy than gender based on markedness or syncretism (e.g., there are many languages with the number category and without gender, but the reverse is rare; and gender is more likely to be the neutralised feature within a given number value and not vice versa Baerman et al., 2005;Corbett, 1991Corbett, , 2000)). However, as discussed above, gender is likely to be linearly closer to the stem when it appears separate form number (Di Garbo, 2014;Kramer, 2015), which would require gender to be higher on the proximity scale. Gender might be considered higher on the related relevance hierarchy as well, given that it can reflect highly specific semantic features of the stem, like sex and animacy.

More recently, alternative explanations of morpheme order focus on the role of distributional cues like the frequency with which stems and affixes (co-)occur. The general idea is that stem+affix pairs that co-occur more frequently together will be more likely to be ordered closer to one another (e.g., Hay, 2001;Hay & Plag, 2004;Ryan, 2010). In some cases, the relevant notion is degree of dependency, or strength of association, which can be quantified using mutual information between stem and affix. Hahn et al. (2021) show that this is a good predictor of the relative order of verbal affixes in a number of different language. Rathi, Hahn, and Futrell (2022) further argue that this same measure can predict patterns of fusion between morphemes (i.e., the degree to which formatives are phonologically intertwined with their host). This is reminiscent of accounts of word order arguing that mutual information can predict linear distance between head and dependents (Culbertson, Schouwstra, & Kirby, 2020;Futrell, Dyer, & Scontras, 2020;Futrell, Mahowald, & Gibson, 2015;Hahn, Jurafsky, & Futrell, 2020). Distributional statistics like these have the potential to make predictions about gender and number. Notably, stems and gender affixes are likely to co-occur very frequently, more so than stems and number markers. For example, in Spanish, where number and gender are not cumulative, singular is zero-marked while gender is always overtly marked. In this case, the co-occurrence frequency (and mutual information) between a stem and a gender morpheme is likely to be higher than between a stem and a number morpheme.foot_7

div.head: Experimental evidence for preferences in morpheme ordering
div.p: The pervasiveness of cumulative exponence of gender-number morphology and scarcity of documented separative exponence makes it difficult to assess whether there is support for theories which predict clear ordering preferences among these two inflectional categories. Moreover, the frequent coexistence of fixed and variable gender within the same system of gender marking make it difficult to explore potential differences in their linguistic representations. However, even if natural language data were plentiful and typological regularities were robustly quantified, cross-linguistic tendencies are not necessarily directly linked to individual-level mental representations or biases.

Tendencies could reflect historical contingencies, cognition-external pathways of change, or even common distributional properties of the linguistic input that reflect communicative needs rather than learning biases or mental representations. For instance, as we have summarised in the previous section, some studies have shown that co-occurrence statistics among stems and morphemes, rather than any abstract representations of their structure, may determine morpheme order and morphological fusion both within and across languages (Hahn et al., 2021;Hahn, Mathew, & Degen, 2022;Hay, 2001;Hay & Plag, 2004;Rathi et al., 2022).

Experimental research offers a way to test these different theories, and in particular to uncover evidence for representations or biases that shape gender and number systems. For example, if particular ways of ordering morphemes are preferred by learners in carefully controlled experiments, this can provide evidence for specific theories or representations. It also provides a potential link between human cognitive biases and typology: individual learners' preferences can be amplified as languages are transmitted from generation to generation (Kirby, Tamariz, Cornish, & Smith, 2015;Thompson, Kirby, & Smith, 2016). In recent work, Saldana et al. (2021) used a series of artificial language learning studies to show that English-and Japanese-speaking participants' inferences about number and case morphemes follow the cross-linguistic trend in having number closer to a noun stem than case. This held even though co-occurrence statistics among stems and different affixes were kept constant. Saldana et al. (2021) argue that this ordering preference therefore likely reflects differences in the kinds of meanings conveyed by these two types of morphemes (e.g., following Bybee, 1985;Culbertson et al., 2020).

Here, we use a similar experimental design to probe the biases of language learners with regards to the relative order of gender and number morphology. We train participants on nominal systems with separative number and gender morphology, but holding out any evidence about the relative order of these morphemes in the language. By holding distributional information-that is, co-occurrence frequencies between stems and morphemes-constant, we can isolate the impact of the features themselves. For example, we can directly test whether learners' biases more closely align with split models of gender and number, or bundling models. As discussed above, split models predict that gender should be linearised closer to the noun than number. By contrast, if gender and number are bundled together, we wouldn't predict any particular ordering pattern to be more likely than another (without further constraints). If these hypothesised structural representations in fact play no role, and order is fully determined by distributional information accessible to the learner during acquisition, then equally, we should see no preference for one order over the other when input frequencies are controlled. In the experiments described below we also explore whether learners' ordering preferences are consistent regardless of experience with gender systems in their L1, and whether preferences differ when participants are taught fixed and variable gender systems.

As mentioned above, in some formal theories, variable and fixed gender have been argued to behave in different ways (with variable gender projecting higher, either with number or with its own head Carminati, 2005;De Vincenzi, 1999;Panagiotidis, 2018), which could potentially impact the strength of any ordering preferences-e.g., weaker for variable gender systems than for fixed gender systems.

div.head: Study 1: ordering preferences for gender and number morphemes across populations
div.p: In the first set of experiments, we train English-, Italian-, and Kîîtharaka-speaking adult participants on miniature nominal paradigms with separative exponence of gender and number morphology. For the sake of simplicity and learnability, we focus on nominal gender marking (and not on agreement targets), and gender assignment is exclusively (and not only partly) based on the semantics of the nouns. Gender assignment can be either based on animacy and fixed (i.e., stems denote either animate or inanimate entities), or based on sex and variable (i.e., stems denote only sex-differentiable entities, and they can be either male or female). We refer to these conditions as animacy-based and sex-based respectively.

Participants' training input indicates whether gender and number affixes generally precede or follow the noun stem (i.e., they are either all prefixes or all suffixes), but crucially participants are not given any examples in which overt gender and number affixes co-occur on the same noun.

Participants thus only know whether the novel language is prefixal or suffixal-gender and number marking can be either both prefixes or both suffixes-but they have no evidence indicating in which way gender and number affixes are ordered when they appear together-both as affixes or both as prefixes-within the same noun. At test, they are asked to produce an order for these held out examples. These productions will reveal the inferences learners make regarding the relative order of gender and number morphology, in the absence of any evidence in the input linguistic system.
We compare across speakers of different languages in order to assess whether substantially different experience with gender systems in their first language impacts the results.

English-speaking participants have an L1 that marks (plural) number on nouns, but does not mark gender. 12 Thus these participants have no evidence from their native language (neither for sex-based nor for animacy-based systems) of how inflectional morphemes of gender and number should be ordered relative to one another. They do, however, have evidence of derivational gender morphemes being placed closer to the root than (inflectional) number (e.g., lion-ess-(e)s), which in the absence of any other gender linguistic representation, could lead to participants placing sexbased gender markers closer to the stem because they treat them as derivational morphology. The animacy-based system we use here is quite distinct from this. Further, in contrast to English, Italianspeaking participants have an L1 which marks both gender and number, but cumulatively (see2-3 above). The system can be characterised as sex-based, with both variable and fixed sub-systems.

If Italian speakers also prefer to place number in the periphery, it will not be because they are only familiar with inflectional affixes with number information alone (see Saldana et al., 2021, for related evidence). Their knowledge of gender also makes it less likely that they would fall back on experience with derivational morphology to determine order. Finally, Kîîtharaka-speaking participants have an L1 that is like Italian in featuring cumulative gender and number. However, like other Bantu languages, it is prefixing. Similar to Kîîtharaka, described above, the Kîîtharaka gender system can be described as containing an animacy-based semantic core. It has a relatively large number of classes, typically treated as singular-plural pairs, with classes partly determined by semantics. The most obviously inflectional semantic feature is human vs. non-human (e.g., CL1 and CL2 nouns are exclusively human, singular and plural respectively; Kanampiu et al., under review). Some Kîîtharaka class markers have been analysed as derivational (since they can be used to express diminutive, augmentative, pejorative meanings). However, unlike English and Italian, Kîîtharaka does not have any derivational morphology that expresses sex differences, and derivational uses of gender morphemes still cumulatively express number. 13 To preview, the order participants across all three languages infer indicates a clear preference for placing gender closest to the noun, in accordance with a representation in which gender is more closely tied to the noun than number is. This is straightforwardly predicted by split models 12 English is not considered to have a (grammatical) gender system. English does not mark gender on the noun and there is no further agreement targets within the language other than on third person singular personal pronouns. 13 As noted above for other Bantu languages, in some cases cumulative derivational-number morphemes can be stacked on top of cumulative gender-number morphemes.

(e.g., Harris, 1991;Kramer, 2015;Picallo, 1991) which argue that gender and number are projected separately, with gender either part of the nominal project or immediately dominating it. By contrast, to account for these results, bundling models would require ad-hoc ordering mechanisms (e.g., Ritter, 1993). We also find that Italian speakers are slightly more likely to produce the reverse orders for variable gender systems than for fixed gender systems. This is not the case for English speakers, where we find no difference between gender systems. These results therefore expand the range of behavioural evidence for the role of cognitive representations in determining morpheme order, and further suggest a possible difference between the representations of gender across variable and fixed systems (consistent with the models proposed in , e.g., Carminati, 2005;De Vincenzi, 1999) worth exploring further in future work.

div.head: Materials and methods
div.p: Our experiments use an extrapolation design to test participants' preferences for gender and number morpheme ordering on nouns (following Saldana et al., 2021). Participants were trained on a subset of a nominal system with two gender classes and two number values (singular and plural). Across all conditions, only one gender class is overtly marked via affixation, the other is not; and only one number value is overtly marked via affixation, the other is not. The system is thus designed such that only some forms involve affixes of both gender and number. Crucially, these forms are held out during training, but participants are asked to infer them during testing. During training, participants therefore learn only how single morphemes are ordered relative to the noun stem. At test, they must therefore infer the relative order of the two. They can either place the gender morpheme closer to the noun stem than the number morpheme, or vice versa.

Experiments with English and Italian speakers were designed using a 2 × 2 betweensubjects factorial design where we manipulated the position of affixes (either all suffixes or all prefixes) and the type of gender system (either animacy-based or sex-based). In one condition, the gender systems mark perceived biological sex of nonhuman animals with sexual dimorphism. For example, the stem alone is used to refer to the animal with female characteristics (FEM), and the stem together with an overt gender affix is used when the same denoted animal shows male characteristics (MASC). We refer to this condition as sex-based, but it also corresponds to what we have called a variable system above, since the same stem encoding a single meaning (type of animal) can be inflected for both genders (here via an overt affix vs zero-marking). The other condition, which we call animacy-based, is closer to what we have called a fixed gender system. In this condition, gender distinguishes between animate (ANIM) and inanimate (INANIM) entities and the denoted entity type cannot be both ANIM and INANIM. Stems denoting animates are marked with an affix, and stems denoting inanimates are zero-marked. 14 . We want to control for stem-affix co-occurrence statistics equally across conditions and we need to share the stem forms across classes in fixed animacy-based systems as well as in variable sex-based systems; the only way to do it by having homophonous stems across classes in the animacy-based condition. The correspondence between the animate and inanimate meanings of two homophonous stems is therefore arbitrary in the fixed animacy-based systems (see 1). Having shared stem forms in both sex-based and animacy-based conditions allows us to match co-occurrence frequencies (and mutual information) between each combination of stem form and affix. Thus learners exposed to both variable and fixed systems must make inferences about order in the absence of distributional information.

The design used for Kîîtharaka speakers diverges from this. After piloting, we determined that these systems were not readily learned by our Kîîtharaka population (described in detail below), therefore we went with a simpler system that is more natural-language-like. 15 Firstly, gender classes convey a more salient animacy distinction for the target population, that is, between humans and inanimate objects. Secondly, in this system, stems are not shared across gender classes, but are unique-as they are mostly in natural language. Note then that here the co-occurrence frequencies of stem+affix combinations are not matched; the same stem form can only appear in a single gender class, and thus stems overtly marked for gender are always marked for gender (and never appear with zero marking). We discuss the implications of this difference in light of the results below.

div.head: Artificial lexicon
div.p: Participants were trained on a language with a small lexicon of four (English and Italian participants) or eight (Kîîtharaka participants) stem formsfoot_10 , and two affixes, one expressing number (singular or plural) and the other expressing gender (sex-based or animacy-based assignment depending on the condition). Across all conditions, singular was always unmarked and plural was marked; similarly, one gender value was always marked with an affix and the other is not. For English and Italian speakers, in sex-based conditions MASC was overtly marked and FEM unmarked (i.e., we ensure that the gender marker is not as straightforwardly mapped to the derivational feminine gender affix in the speakers' native languages); in animacy-based system, ANIM was marked and INANIM unmarked. For Kîîtharaka participants INANIM was always unmarked as well. The two affixes were randomly chosen by-participant from the set {gu, sa, vi} (English), {gu, sa, di} (Italian), or {ke, bu, ra} (Kîîtharaka).foot_11 Gender and number affixes were attached to stems, with the relative order of affixes and nouns (prefixing or suffixing) determined by the condition. For English and Italian participants, we tested both suffixing and prefixing, for Kîîtharaka participants we tested only prefixing. Examples of a full lexicon for each gender system type and each language population are shown in Table 1. 18During training phases (described below), participants saw three kinds of nominal forms in the language: the stem alone (singular, unmarked class), gender-marked stems (singular, marked class), and number-marked stems (plural, unmarked class). Crucially, forms in which both a number and gender overt morphology would be required-i.e., plural, gender-marked class-were held out. As noted above, for English and Italian, each of the four stems is used equally frequently in both gender classes, and with both numbers, therefore no co-occurrence statistics that differentiate stem+number from stem+gender combinations are present during training. In Kîîtharaka, because stems are not shared across classes, marked gender class stems always occurred with the gender marker. Thus co-occurrence statistics would indicate to participants that stem+gender combinations are more frequent.

div.head: Experimental procedure
div.p: The experiments were programmed using JsPsych (De Leeuw, 2015) and displayed in participants' browser window. Before starting the experiment proper, participants were told they would learn how to describe simple pictures in a new language. The training phase was divided into three sub-phases: exposure, picture-matching, and recall. During exposure, participants saw images along with orthographically presented nouns using a stem alone, or a stem with a single affix (either number or gender). More specifically, they were trained on three different types of inflected forms (see Table 1): the stem alone (G1.SG, where SG → / 0 and G1 → / 0), gender marked stems (G2.SG, where SG → / 0 and G2 → affix), and number marked stems (G1.PL, where PL → affix and G1 → / 0). Participants saw each stem in each of these three forms five times, for a total of 60 trials (randomly ordered for each participant). In the picture-matching phase, participants saw two images and a form and had to click the corresponding image. As in the exposure phase, forms featured either a stem alone, or a stem with a single morpheme (either number of gender). The foil image for each trial was either the wrong gender, or the wrong number. Participants saw each stem with each pairing of correct and foil three times, for a total of 48 matching trials (randomly ordered for each participant). In the recall phase, participants were tested on the forms they had been trained on so far (i.e., G1.SG, G1.PL and G2.SG). In each trial, they saw an image and had to construct the corresponding form by clicking buttons. The button set always included the correct stem, the gender affix, and the number affix, but these were randomly ordered on each trial. Full feedback was provided. Participants saw each stem inflected for G1.SG, G1.PL and G2.SG three times (36 trials in total, randomly ordered for each participant).

In the critical testing phase, participants were tested on the held-out G2.PL form-meaning mappings: where both G2 gender and PL number are overtly marked, and therefore they need to provide forms with the two affixes. Participants saw an image and had to construct an inflected form by clicking buttons. The button set always included the correct stem, the marked gender affix (depending on the condition), and the number PL affix, but these were randomly ordered on each trial. Participants had to use all three buttons and could not submit their answer until they did. No other feedback was provided. Participants saw each inflected stem three times (total of 12 trials, randomly ordered for each participant).

div.head: Participants
div.p: English and Italian-speaking participants were recruited through Prolific (www.prolific.co) and paid 10 GBP/h for participation in the study, which took approximately 12 minutes. We used Prolific screening criteria to include native English-and Italian-speaking participants who were Table 1 raised monolingual and whose primary language is still their native language. 19Kîîtharaka-speaking participants were recruited via local contacts in Kenya (specifically, in Tharaka-Nithi county, the main region where the language is spoken). Participants were largely students of Tharaka University, most of whom were multilingual speakers of Swahili, English or both. Participants were sent a link to the experiment, and after completing the experiment, they were paid 400 KES.

As per our preregistration, participants who got less than 75% correct on recall trials in the training phase were excluded (N = 9 both for English and for Italian, and N = 1 for Kîîtharaka). 20 For English and Italian speakers, a total of 80 participants' data were analysed for each language (20 in each condition of our 2x2 factorial design). For Kîîtharaka speakers, a total of 28 participants' data was analysed (in a single condition, as described above).

div.head: Data analysis
div.p: For each population tested, we used R's brms (Bürkner, 2018) library as an interface to
Stan (Carpenter et al., 2017) to fit a mixed-effects Bayesian binomial model predicting participants' production of gender-closest order (stem-G2-PL if suffixing or PL-G2-stem if prefixing).

Our dependent variable was participants' responses for each of the critical test trials (coded as 1 if gender-closest, and 0 if number-closest). For English and Italian, we included fixed effects of affix position (suffixing vs prefixing, treatment-coded) and gender system (sex-based vs animacybased, treatment-coded), as well as their interaction. As random effects, we included intercepts for participants as well as stems. We set the same Student-t prior on all fixed effects and intercepts (DF = 6, µ = 0, σ = 1.5); for random effects' standard deviations, we set a half-Cauchy prior with a scale parameter 1. The model for the experiment with Kîîtharaka speakers was intercept-only (as we only have one condition); the same random effects structure and priors were set as in the previous models.

We ran two further models, one comparing the experiments with English and Italian speakers and another one comparing the prefix animacy-based conditions across all three linguistic populations (Kîîtharaka, English and Italian). In the former model we used the same model structure as the one described for English and Italian above with the added fixed effect of language group (English vs Italian) and an interaction term. In the latter model, we used the same model as for the experiment of Kîîtharaka speakers alone but instead of an intercept-only model, we add the effect of linguistic population (Kîîtharaka, English and Italian). We used Kîîtharaka as the baseline, since the artificial system was designed to mirror closely that of Kîîtharaka-with the only difference being that morphology was separative-and the co-occurrence statistics in the experiment with Kîîtharaka speakers were much stronger between stems and gender affixes than between stems and number affixes.

div.head: Results
div.p: Based on our preregistered hypothesis, we predicted that participants would prefer to place gender morphology closer to the stem than number morphology in systems where both gender and number affixes are separate and both are placed before or after the stem. In the experiments with English and Italian speakers, we further explore whether participants are equally likely to produce gender-closest orders across animacy-based (fixed) and sex-based (variable) gender systems. As a reminder, in variable systems lexical stems map to a single meaning and are inflected for different gender feature values (as in the sex-based system in our experiments); in fixed gender systems lexical stems are either shared idiosyncratically across classes (as in the animacy-based systems in our English and Italian experiments), or are not shared at all (as in the animacy-based system in our Kîîtharaka experiment).

Figure 4 shows average proportions of gender-closest orders in the critical trials for participants in the populations and conditions we tested. A visual inspection suggests that our results are consistent with the preregistered predictions: participants infer gender-closest orders (i.e., stem-G2-PL or PL-G2-stem), regardless of affix position, the type of gender system, or the participant population.

div.head: Discussion
div.p: The set of experiments in Study 1 tested whether language learners with different native languages would infer that a novel gender morpheme should be ordered closer to the noun stem, with a novel number morpheme placed peripherally. As described above, the precise systems participants were taught differed across populations. Importantly, the training input we used for English and Italian speakers was designed so that no co-occurrence statistics would lead learners to prefer one order over the other (suggested as a mechanism for ordering preferences by, e.g., Hahn et al., 2022).

In other words, stems occurred equally frequently with the gender and number morpheme. This was not the case for Kîîtharaka-speakings participants, for whom we used a simplified language that resembled typical natural language gender systems: stems marked with an overt gender affix always occurred with that affix. Nevertheless, our results confirm a strong preference for oredring gender morphemes closer to the stem than number morphemes across all populations. The fact that the preference was equally strong across these populations suggests that higher co-occurrence frequencies are not necessary to skew participants' performance in favour of gender-closest order.

The similar strength of preference regardless of native language experience with gender further suggests that the preferences are not driven by knowledge of the relative order of derivational and inflectional affixes. While this could potentially explain English speakers' placement of gender closer to the stem-i.e., if their lack of experience with gender leads them to treat this morpheme as derivational-it is not likely to explain the results for Italian or Kîîtharaka speakers. Italian speakers arguably don't have any reason to treat the systems they are trained on here as anything other than akin to gender in their language. Kîîtharaka does not have derivational morphology that can be separated from number.

The results are also unlikely to be explained by differences in participants' ability to learn or correctly interpret the meanings of gender and number morphemes. Training phase accuracy (in picture-matching and recall tests) for English and Italian speakers were uniformly high. The proportions of correct interpretations of the affixes in the post-experimental survey were also high.

Proportions of English and Italian participants reporting the correct interpretations provided for gender morphemes were between 70-75% in animacy-based systems and 85-100% in sex-based systems, and interpretations provided for number morphemes were correct across 85-100% of participants. Most Kîîtharaka-speaking participants (93%) also provided correct interpretations for number morphology in the post-experiment questionnaire; however, only 38% of participants provided correct interpretations for the gender morphology, suggesting that the gender markers in this experiment-which, unlike in the other experiments, were attached to stems which were never seen in isolation-were potentially harder to process as separate morphology and they were most likely processed as part of the stem.

It is also worth noting that participants inferred the predicted order regardless of whether the system was prefixal or suffixal, confirming that this preference is not about the sequential order of the morpheme-i.e., which one is linearly first absolutely-but about the which morpheme should be closer to the noun stem. We also found that the preference towards number-closest orders is consistent across sex-based variable gender, and animacy-based fixed gender systems. This suggests that the interpretation of gender across the board leads to a gender-first derivation-i.e., gender combines morphosyntactically with the stem first-separate from number.

Moreover, we generally found that the type of gender system-fixed or variable-did not substantially alter the strength of the preference for gender-closest orders. That said, we did find a slight difference in the likelihood of producing the reversed number-closest order across gender system types: both English and Italian speakers tended to produce this reverse order slightly more often in sex-based variable systems. This might be taken to suggest that gender morphemes are more likely to be treated as separate from the stem when the stem is used to derive related entities (e.g., male vs. female of a given animal as in our sex-based condition). This is potentially in line with theories that posit that gender is derived with the noun stem in fixed systems and with number in variable systems (e.g., De Vincenzi, 1999). However, given the strength of the overall preference, we cannot rule out the possibility that our sample size is insufficient to assert the difference found across fixed and variable gender, and that datapoints driving the effect might be outliers (see fig. 4).

Altogether, these results suggest that speakers' mental representations of gender and number impact ordering preferences. In particular, these representations are such that gender is consistently placed closer to the noun stem than number morphology is. This overwhelming preference cannot be straightforwardly explained by theories which bundle together gender and number features, such as the one proposed for Romance languages in (Ritter, 1993). Nor can it be explained by distributional information alone (Hahn et al., 2022). Rather, this preference mirrors a trend in the typology of separative gender-number systems captured by theories that argue for a representation of gender together with (or closest to) the noun (Alexiadou, 2004;Harris, 1991;Kramer, 2015Kramer, , 2016a;;Mel'čuk, 2013). Of course, the pervasiveness of cumulative gender-number marking in noun affixes still requires explanation. Our findings point toward alternative mechanisms, for example the grammaticalisation of gender systems. We return to this in the general discussion.

Before that, however, we return to the observation that the tendency to place the expression of gender closer to the noun is also found in double plurals (Di Garbo, 2014;Kramer, 2016b). In the examples provided above in section 1.1 for Kinshassa Lingala (see 7), an affix which expresses gender and number cumulatively is placed closer to the stem than a general number affix (which does not express any gender feature). Kramer (2016b) describes a similar tendency for the double plurals found in Amharic (Afro-Asiatic). In Amharic there is a general plural marker which can be used with all stems, (which she calls regular plural) and other plural markers which can only be used only with a restricted set of stems (which she refers to as irregular plurals). Both types of plural markers can co-occur on the same nominal form simultaneously, and in these doubly marked plural nouns, the more restricted number marker is always closer to the stem than the general number marker. This recurrent double plural pattern suggests that number expressions might not all be equivalently represented. In particular, we might expect that general number morphemes might be represented as hierarchically higher than gender-specific (i.e., restricted to a class of stems) number morphemes (Kramer, 2016b) when these are bundled together. Assuming that linear proximity mirrors local structural relationships between morphemes (e.g., Bobaljik, 2012;Embick, 2010), this would explain why they are realised closer to the stem cross-linguistically.

Interestingly, the system Kîîtharaka-speaking participants learned in Study 1 could be somewhat parallel to this. Given their native language experience-i.e., extensive cumulative marking of gender and number-these participants may have learned that the gender affix was a cumulative singular-human class morpheme, and that the number affix was a cumulative plural-inanimate class morpheme. If so, then essentially, the test phase requires them to disregard the class information in the plural morpheme and use it as a general plural at test. This is of course, highly speculative.
In the following section we present an experiment explicitly testing ordering preferences of general and gender-specific plural affixes in double plural constructions.

This experiment serves two purposes. First, it allows us to test whether plurals carrying the expression of gender are consistently placed closer to the stem by language learners. If so, this would provide support for the idea that any morpheme carrying gender information should be closer to the stem than any morpheme not carrying such information. This in turn would suggest that distinct representations of number can exist. Second, since both morphemes will express plural (which is more straightforwardly an inflectional category in participants' L1), this experiment will allow us to confirm even more strongly that the results of the first set of experiments are not driven by a bias to place derivational (or more derivational-like) morphology closer to the stem than inflectional morphology.
3 Study 2: ordering biases for general and gender-specific number morphemes

Following our previous study, here we use an artificial language learning paradigm to test whether the inferences learners make about the order of gender-specific (here, gender-encoding) and general (here, non-gender-encoding) number morphology support the idea that these two types of number morphemes are represented distinctly. In particular, gender-specific plurals are hypothesised to be lower in the hierarchy or derived earlier than general plurals, which are higher in the hierarchy (Kramer, 2016b). 22 As in the previous experiments, here we control for any effects of input statistics on participants' ordering preferences. In this case, we explicitly compare order preferences for stems where co-occurrence statistics are balanced, and those which are not. This is explained in more detail below.

div.head: Materials and methods
div.p: As in the set of experiments in Study 1 above, here we use an extrapolation design. We train native English speakers on a subset of a nominal system with two gender classes (human and non-human) and two number values (singular and plural). Plurals are overtly marked in this system, and they can be marked with a productive general plural affix or a plural affix that is restricted to a particular gender class. During testing, we ask participants to produce double plurals for the nouns they have been trained on, that is, to use both general and gender-specific plural affixes together.
The experiment features a 2 × 2 between-subjects factorial design where we manipulate the type of affixation (suffixing or prefixing) and the order of the training blocks of the different plural

div.head: Artificial lexicon
div.p: Participants were trained on a language with a small lexicon of 8 stems, and 3 affixes. Stems belonged to one of two gender classes, the first containing human referents, the second containing inanimate referents (the same meanings used in the Kîîtharaka experiment in Study 1). There were four stems in each gender class. All three morphemes expressed plural meaning, but one (the general plural) co-occurs with all stems, and two (the gender-specific plurals) co-occur only with stems in a given gender class. All plural affixes are attached to stems, both either as prefixes or suffixes, depending on the condition (randomly assigned for each participant at the beginning of the experiment).

An example of the artificial lexicon participants are trained on is provided in table 2. During training, participants see half of the stems for each class with both general and gender-specific plurals (unrestricted stems) and the other half only with the gender-specific plurals (restricted stems).

This allows us to (1) show participants that there is a plural that is not dependent on gender while the other two are, (2) match the frequency of all plural morphemes, and (3) maintain the same point-wise mutual information across affixes and a subset of stems. The latter is discussed further below.

div.head: Experimental procedure
div.p: The experiment was programmed using JsPsych (De Leeuw, 2015) and displayed in participants' browser window. Before starting the experiment proper, participants were told they would learn "how to describe objects and people" in a new language. The training phase was divided into three sub-phases: exposure, picture-matching, and recall. In the final critical testing phase, we ask participants to produce doubly marked plurals and thus add the two affixes (general and gender-specific) to the stems.

During the exposure phase, participants saw images along with orthographically-presented descriptions using a stem alone, or a stem with a single plural affix (either general or genderspecific). In the first block, they were exposed to bare stems, which expressed singular meanings.

Participants saw each bare stem twice (i.e., twice for each of the four human stems and twice for each of the four inanimate stems, 16 trials in total, randomly ordered for each participant). In two subsequent blocks they were taught general and gender-specific plurals separately. The order of the general and gender-specific plural training blocks was determined randomly for each participant.

Before the first plural training block, participants were told they would be learning"how to form plurals, that is, how to refer to a group of objects or people". Before the second plural training block, participants were told that this is not the only way to refer to groups of objects or people, and that there is another way which they will proceed to learn. In the gender-specific plural block, they saw each of the eight stems four times with the corresponding plural marker (total of 32 trials, randomly ordered for each participant). In the general plural block, they saw only four stems (two assigned to human gender and two to inanimate, see section 3.1.1 above), four times each (total of 16 trials, randomly ordered for each participant).

Importantly, this training regime entails that point-wise mutual information (pmi) between any combination of plural affix (general or gender-specific) and unrestricted stem (those that appear both with both types of plurals) is exactly the same (pmi = 0.585). This is important because it means participants could not use co-occurrence statistics in the input to inform their decision about whether to order gender-specific or general plurals closer to these stem. For restrictive-only stems (which only appear with a gender-specific plural morpheme) the pmi between stems and affixes is higher (pmi = 1.585). Thus in principle participants could use this kind of distributional asymmetry to guess the order of plural morphemes. In the test phase (described below) participants were asked to form double plurals with both variable and restrictive-only stems; they do so for unrestricted stems first.

In the next part of the training, the picture matching phase, participants saw two images and a description (using a stem alone or a stem and one plural affix, either general or gender-specific) and had to click the corresponding image. The foil image for each trial was either the wrong gender or the wrong number. Participants saw each stem twice in the singular, twice with the gender-specific plural, and each restricted stem was seen twice in the general plural (40 trials total, 16 singular, 16 gender-specific plural, 8 general plural, randomly ordered for each participant). Co-occurrence statistics were held constant as described for the previous exposure phase.

In the recall phase, participants were tested on the forms they had been trained on. In each trial, they saw an image and had to construct the corresponding form by clicking buttons. The buttons always included the correct stem and two affixes. For plural trials, the two affix buttons were the target affix and a foil, the incorrect gender-specific plural affix. For singular trials, the two affix buttons (both foils) were the general plural affix and the gender-specific plural affix matching the stem. Trials were constructed so that the co-occurrence statistics were maintained as in the previous phases. The general plural was never a foil affix, only a target. Therefore, no explicit evidence is provided in this phase that restricted stems cannot be pluralised with general plurals. Participants saw each of the bare stems or stem+affix combinations they were trained on three times (total of 60 trials, i.e., 24 singular, 24 gender-specific plurals, and 12 general plurals, randomly ordered for each participant).

In the critical testing phase, participants were asked to produce double plurals. Participants were reminded that they "have learned that there are two ways of forming plurals" and were told that "speakers of this language can actually use both together". On each trial, participants saw a plural image and had to construct a doubly-marked form by clicking buttons. The buttons on each trial included the stem, the correct gender-specific plural affix (i.e., the one that matches the gender class of the stem) and the general plural affix. Participants had to use all three buttons and could not submit their answer until they did. No other feedback was provided. In the first block of testing, participants only saw unrestricted stems, that is, stems which appeared with both types of plurals during training. They were asked to produce double plurals three times for each unrestricted stem (total of 12 trials, randomly ordered for each participant). Recall that for these items, the frequency of all single affix-stem combinations during training is the same (pmi = 0.585) and there is thus no evidence that one or the other plural affix is more closely associated with a stem based on cooccurrence statistics. In the second block of testing, participants saw restricted stems. They were asked to produce double plurals three times for each restricted stem (total of 12 trials, randomly ordered for each participant). For these items, there is a higher point-wise mutual information between the gender-specific plural affixes and stems (pmi = 1.585) compared to general plurals and stems. There was no break between these blocks.

div.head: Participants
div.p: English-speaking participants were recruited through Prolific as in our previous experiments and paid 10 GBP/h for participation in the study, which took approximately 15 minutes. We used Prolific screening criteria to include only native English-speaking participants who were raised monolingual and whose primary language is still their native language. As per our preregistration, participants whose accuracy was lower than 90% in the last block of the single morpheme production phase during training were excluded. We also excluded participants who did not produce both affixes (as both suffixes or prefixes) during testing. After exclusions (N =35), a total of 120 participants' data was analysed (30 in each condition of our 2x2 factorial design).

div.head: Data analysis
div.p: We ran Bayesian logistic regression models to test whether participants were more likely to produce gender-specific plural morphemes (containing gender information) closer to the stems than the general plural morpheme (without gender information). The model fixed effects were affix position (treatment coding, suffixal vs prefixal), training block order (dummy coded, irregular first = 0, and regular first = 1), and stem type (treatment coded, with restricted stems vs. unrestricted stems), and their interactions. As random effects, we included intercepts for participant and gender class (human or non-human), and by-participant slopes for the effects of stem type.
